cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Oruba" will leave Suez about October 5
R.M.S "Ophir" will leave Suez about October 19.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said October 23
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Port Said October 8

Return tickets are not issued, but passengers paying the full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of one-third of their fare back if the return voyage be made within 4 months of arrival, or an abatement of 20% if the return voyage be made within 6 months of arrival.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Lesbos July 20 from Antwerp.
S.S. Androos July 20 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
S.S. Lemnos July 31 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.

R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d’Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l’étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d’effets sur l’Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

div.head: COMPTOIR NATIONAL D’ESCOMPTE
div.p: DE PARIS.
CAPITAL: 150,000,000 frs,-£ 6,000,000 FULLY PAID UP. — HEAD OFFICE: 14, Rue Bergere, Paris
Alexandria Branch 11, Rue Cherif Pacha.—40 Branches in Paris, and 112 Throughout France.

Branches in London, Liverpool, Manchester, Morocco, Tunis, East India, Madagascar, Australia, etc. Bills Collected. Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods, Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers Issued. Foreign Exhange Bought and Sold. Stocks and Valuables received in safe custody. Purchase and Sale of Stock & Shares in Egypt and Abroad. Dividends Collected.

div.head: BANK OF ATHENS, LIMITED.
div.p: Head Office : Athens — Capital 20,000.000 (Fully paid up). — Reserve 1,000,000.

Patras, Yolo, Syra, Calamata. The Bank undertakes all banking business in Egypt, Greece, etc. Interests on cash deposits,
3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0 per ann. for 6 months; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months; 5 0/0 per ann. for 3 years and over. Savings
Bank Branch receives deposits at 3 1/2 0/0 per ann., from P.T. 80 to P.T. 20,000. 19-1-907

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,340,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d’Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d’un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d’un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: HOTEL BRISTOL. CAIRO.
div.p: Full South, Electric Light, opposite Esbekieh Gardens, Large Verandahs, Moderate Charges,

I. —Installation of complete Water supplies for drinking, agricultural, and
industrial purposes by means of artesian wells.

II. - Deep borings for prospecting purposes in all conditions of soil by means of the
“Express Boring System."

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: Sudan Government
div.p: Notice

Peraona importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to enter into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labourers in presence of an official or other reliable witness.

div.head: REMARKS.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER.
ESTABLISHED 1880.
Editor and Manager - -.R. SNELLING.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1906.

ferry could be made ; probably will be mado. The scheme was explained in some detail at a mratiog of the Briti h Chamber of Commerce in Paris. The president, Mr. Boddington, road a paper showing what might be dong at a comparatively small cost. Moreover, we should not have very long to wait for the facilities. Whereas a tunnel, even if it were approved on grounds of pablio policy, wɔold oooopy many years in construction and cost millions various ly estimated at from right to twonty, a forry could ba set working in two years, and would Antail an expenditure of less than ono million. There is one strong argument in favour of the ferry. We oould use it ourselver. We should not be obliged to construct it, with melanoholy side-glances on the shortness of human lite, ter the benefit of those who are to come sfter 08.

It is true that among the other benefits of the ferry the abolition of rea-sickness would not be incloded. Perhaps our fangs would be less agonising than at preapnt. After experience of the inadequacy of "infallible" romedios the cautions prophetis onwilling to commit himself on the point so much is tolerably certaid, huw. ever, that the torment of prospection sod retro

peotion would be lessened. The journey would pot be broken; it would be completed in quickor time; therefore, we should not have so long to brood over the woe to some and the wce that is past. Having been ron down to Dover, oar train would be ran on to the terry-boat, i he travellers remaining comfortably in their c mpartments, and would be conveyed over he water by a swift turbine. Arrived at Calais, it would be restored to the metals, passengers still remaining in their seata, and be taken to Paris without let or hindrance. The gain in time would be mach. The gain in comfort would be more. At its worst, the sobamo

romises to contrast with the prosent method as favourably as an exprees railway journey compares with a journey made in stopping trains and accompanied by the wretobed neonssity of changes. neem to bave regarded it only as a provisional expedient- something that will serve very well indeed until a project for tunnolling the Channel is carried into effet. We have rl eady expressed our conviotion of the insaperable disadvantages of this bigger scheme. 0.j grounds of pablic polioy we believe it will be batter for all parties that the Channel sball not be undermined.

It has served as well in the past, and will continue to serve ce well; but if sacrilegious bunds te laid opon it, the way may be pavad for trouble that our great-great grandebildren will be compe'led to grapple with amid curses on the temsrity of th sir forefathers. No such obj.otion can be arged to a Channel ferry. It would leave us as beneficially islandad and isolated as we are now. At the same time, it would bring us into oloser communiontion with the Continent.

div.head: Bulletin De La Bourse
div.p: Auiourd'hui a midi et demie

Le marche a ouvert ce matin en pleine depression, pour se ressaisir un pen plus tard et cloturer relativement soutenu. Nombre de valeurs sont, cependant en baisse plus ou moins sensible. Cette reaction provient de la liquidation de fin de mois et de l'impression defavorable produite par la baisse du coton americain

La National Bank recale de 27 7/8 a 27 1/4, l'Alexandria Water de 13 7/8 a 13 3,4 la Daira de 17 5/16 a 17 1/4, la Cassa di Sconto de 243 1/4 a 242 l'ancienne et de 238 1/2 a 237 1/2 la nouvelle, lee Nungovich Hotels de 18 5/16 a 18 3/16, la Nile Land de 17 7/16 a 17 3/8, la Land Bank de 9 a 8 15/16, l'Urbaine de 6 11/16 a 6 19/32, le Credit Franco-Egyptien de 5 9/16 a 5 17/ 38 et la Banque d'Orient de 134 a 133.
De 25/3 la Salt and Soda reactionne aussia 25, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 39/9 a 39.
Par contre, les Cotton Mills montent de 7/3 a 7/6, les Lots Turos de 149 a 152, les Sucreries de 23 1/2 a 29 1/4, la Khedivial Mail de 4 5/8 a 4 11/16, et le Banco di Rama de 113 a 113 1/2.
Quant au Comptoir, tandis que l'action flechit de 7 1/8 et 6 7/8 a 7 1/16 et 6 13/16, la part de fondateur remonte de 52 1/2 a 53.

Les Estates sont tres fermes a 2 1/4 et ont donne lieu a heaucoup d'affaires, ainsi que le Comptoir et la Delta Land; cette derniere est un peu plus faible a 4 3/32 vendenrs. Sur le reste de la cote, le mouvement a e e presque nul.

Toutes les antres valenrs restent sans changement excepte l'union Fonciere qui perd encoure 1/16 a 6 7/16. Nous n'avona pas besoin de dire que ce prix estres avantageux, car l'Union Fonciere sera certainement dan quel ques jours l'une des devises les plus rechereheas de la cote. En effet, c'est a la fin de 1906 que la societe doit proclamer son premier bilan qui fera ressortir es situation exceptionuellement florisrante. Nous donnerons prochainement des reneseignements detailles a ce aujet

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: Notes Et Critiques

Le Caire, Novembre 5. Samedi pravé, au Stook Erehango de Londres lo Consolidé soglais regagné 1/8 & 46 5/8 L'Unifico s'est maintonge à 102 1/4. La Na tional Bank et l'Agricole sont restées in variées à 27 17 97/8, de même que la Daïra à 17 8/8. La Delta Light » avance de 1,8 * 12 1/4
A Paris, l'action Crédit Popoier Bgyption réactionné de 3 franos . 788. La Banque d'A thènes • progressé 148. L'Enpront ragee

Le Ontdit Fonciera rétrogradé à 789 et en part de fondateur à 970. La Daïra s'est alourdie à 17 /161/4. La Behérs molli à 44. L'Union Pohoière. parda 1/16 à 6 9/16.
La Nie land s'est insorite à 17 7/16-1/2 et le Wardat Batata à 7 3,8-7/16. Les Improvemonts ont débuté & 6 5/8 pour téchir à 69/16 et romoster en oltare . 6 11/16-8/4.
La Ratreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont fini 145/8 et la part de tondateur à 95-96. WAllotment 3 oommapoé à 4 1/8-3/16 pour faiblir à 8 15/16-4 ; la part de fondatear est revenu 3 166.
La Delta Light été mioux tende à 12 1/16 1/8. Les Jouissanoo. Baux da Caire ont été ootées 972, mans acheteurs.
L'Anglo-American Nile a été l'objet d'une bonne demande, qui la portés à 6 1/8 pour terminer à 6. Leo Medzieb opt faibli à 3 7/8 et les Automobiles à 6-6 1/16.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nangovicb ne sont tassés à 18 5/16 et les Eeyptian à 7 9/16-8/8. LUpper Egypt ont perdo 1/16 5 1/8 et løNational antant al 4 4 1/16.

Parmi les petites valegre, la Delta Land a flécbi 44 1/16. I es Estates se sont raffer mis à 9 1/4 ; leur part de fondateur a avancé * 15 5/16-8/8. Las Hooker sont revenas à 1 1/16-1/8, les Constructions à 1 9/ 6 6,8, les Markets & 27 sh. 9 et les Salt and Soda a 25 h. Las Bucreries ont avaosé do 96 A 27-29 franos, lo Kbodivial Mail à 39 ab, 9 et les Walker epd Maimarahi à 0 11/16-8/4.

Ainsi que nous l'avions fait remarquer dans potre Circulaire d'avant-hier, on ne marajt ensore rien, affirmer au sujet des roments répaodoes soron pjat de fusion entre la Compagpie Immobil'ère d'Egypte et la Compa gnie Agricole da Nil; les renseignements précis font cbfant, les administrateurs locaux des deux Sociétés étant absente.

Todjnun at-il qu'on mouvement sur les titres de l'Agricole da Nil est absolument in dépendant de ce projet ou préteudo projet.. Il se basprait rationnellement sur le fait materiel que la Société fait den reggisitions in pirts ptes de terrains, dont le plus-valge at
aojnord’bai de, plas de 60%, alors que l'action resto . 10% on viron au-dessus de son prix d'émission.

Og mait que par suite du développement et d' u suocès de 988 opérations foncières, la Compagnie a dû récemment doubler son capital par l'émission de 12,000 notions dog velles de 2:0 franos ebaoane, et nous avons ADDODOÉ, avant-hier même, qu'elle s9 propose d'émettre pour 6 millions de fracos d'obligations afin d'acorul;r mes DOBROQTOOS. et en même temps en bénéfices.
8998 se dernier rapport, les résultats exceptionnels de l'ex fraice on coars légitimant déjà pleinement de banane rapide da titre.
Nous détachows d'ave lettre de Londres, en date da 27 0 store, la pasango agivant :

"Am anjet de la tension monétaire, il est intéressant de suivre le mor vement qoi, obaqae année, en automne, entralne Vor de la Banquo d'Angleterre vers des destinations diverses, sans compter les sommes qui sont puisées sur lem: rebé libre.

"Pendant les trois mois de Septembre, Octobre et Novembre de: années 1903, 1904 et 1965, cos sorties se sont élevées respectivement. £6,087,000 (dont 4,095,000 pour V Beypte). 6,252 000 (dont 3,6 20,000 poor l'Egypte et 1,4-3,000 pour l'Amérique da Sad) et 8,795,000 (dont 1.620,000 pour l'Egypte et 1.643,000 pour l'Amérique du Sud).

Or, cette année, da ler Septembre an 24 Octobre, l'Egypte seale a déjà pris £5,260.000; les Etats-Upis, dont les demandes avaient été insignifiantes les années précédentes, ont demandé 3 590.000 ; enfin 1 million pris la direction de Constantinople.

"Cela fait au total 9,850,000, sans compter quelqnes mondes sommes ayant pris d'autres directions, et l'on voi qoe la part de l’Egypte & été déjà beaucoap plus forte pour moins de deux mois qu'elle de l's été pour le trimestre tout entier pendaot les trois derdières années.

"Grâce à 006 merveilleuse récolte et à la balese des prix on estime à £.0 millions le montant des exportations de coton que pourra faire l’Egypto, soit £5 millions de plus que le chiffre de la réoolte précédente, et l'on s'atton drait de oe chef à on noavesa drainage d'or de £3 millions sur le marché de Londres."

div.head: Au New Khedivial Hotel
div.p: Exposition De Chapsaux

Mademoiselle Odette qui est de passage a Alexandrie aveo un tres joli choix de chapeaux des principales maisons de Paris, telles que Raboux, Camille Roger, Esther Meyer, etc., fera a partir de deamin a l'Hotel Khedivial une exposition de chapeaux quielle prie les. aimables lectrices de "l'Egyptian Gazette" de voiloir bien visiter. Cete exposition durera seulement trois jours, apres le quals Mademoiselle Odetter se rendta au Caire. and Co.

div.head: Telegrams.
div.p: Mutiny At Portsmouth
Naval Canteen Smashed Up.
London, November 5.

A serious outbreak ocurred in the naval barracks at Portsmouth yesterday. 300 men on parade bolted indoors without orders during a rain equally. They were afterwards paraded in the Gymnasium, when the senior officer ordered the front rank, mostly composed of stokers, to kneel in order that he might better see and address them. So me of them hesitated one returned and was handed over to the naval police. His comrades, being relentful, afterwards smashed up the canteen and resolved to wreck the quarters of the officer. but the alarm being given, the whole force in the barracks was mobilised by bugle call and the rioters confronted with fixed bayonets. They eventually retired. After Commodore Stopford had listened to their grievances he ordered the release of the prisoner. (Reuter)

div.head: France And Disarmament
div.p: M. Clemenceau's Policy.
Paris, November 5

The Chamber of Deputies approved by 395 votes to 96 M. Clemenceau's declaration, which stated that while the peace of the world depends on force of arms France cannot disarm, and that he will be careful to maintain and develop an alliance contracted in the interests of peace as well as tried frienships (Reuter)
Paris, November 5.

Chamber of Deputies-The Ministerial declaration adds that the Cabinet will introduce a Bill for the suppression of courts marital, conciliating the rights of man with the necessities of national defence. It will accomplish the secularisation of the schools, will abrogate the Falloux law, will establish the liberty of the cults, and will realise workmen's pensions and the income tax
The Chamber passed a vote of confidence by 395 votes against 96. (Havas)

div.head: Greece And Bulgaria
div.p: Probable Rupture
Sofia, November 5
The government having refused to compensate the Greeks for the losses sustained in the recent anti-Greek riots, the Greek representative will go on leave, and will probably not return. (Reuter)

div.head: The Search For The Pole
div.p: Peary To Make Second Attempt
New York, November 5

Commander Peary is returning for repairs and additional supplies and will again make an attempt to reach the Pole. The recent dash was frustrated by a mild season; but despite the delays, owing to much borken ice and open water, he got within 203 miles of the Pole. (R.)

div.head: Keir Hardie On The Elections
div.p: London, November 5

Mr. Keir Hardie, speaking at Edinburgh denied that Socialism or the Labour party bad received a set back from the result of the monicipal elections. The defeat of the Progressives in London meant the triumph of great electric and other trusts, which had spent 52000 fighting the elections. (Reuter)

div.head: An American Dreadnought
div.p: Washington, November 5
The Naval Department contemplates bulding a more powerful ship than the Dreadnought. She is to have a displacement of 20,500 tons (Reuter)

div.head: The Indian Review
div.p: The October number of the "Indian Review" contains an interesting article from an Indian publicist, "India's Imports". He arrives at the conclusion the people import goods of the value of RS 338 and silver of the value of 2 3/4 annas per head per annum, and this single fact, the writer avers, "is eveidence enough of the extremely poor economic condition of the people." Pandit Jwala Dott Joshi writing about 'The Impersonality of the British Indian Empire," suggests the desirability of a member of the Royal family of England governing India instead of a Viceroy as at repent.

div.head: Education In Egypt
div.p: Native Press Opinion
(From 'Al Moayad.")
"No advance can be made in the educational state of a nation unless the system of training in that nation answers all her needs". (Report of Lord Cromer, 1903)

The policy followed by the Ministry of Education in the system of training is that the primary schools should be the means of making those who attend them able as much as possible to read and write; and that the Ministry should endeavour to display to the Government its great attention and concern to advance arts. But the truth is that the ministry is absolutely indifferent on that point. The only object of the secondary and higher training is to prepare Government employes. Official training meets only some of the nation's wants and spreads among a fraction of the people. How many times has the Legislative Council raised its voice, asking that all regulations relating to educational training should be submitted to it? But the answer of the Government was always that the Legislative Council has nothing to do with regulations relating to educational training. Assuming that the rules of the Legislative Council do not allow its interference with such regulations, which is certainly untrue, are not the pupils that attend Government
